lexUnit.name: exasperation.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the state of being angry or irritated

sentence.text: ` There is exasperation that it is taking so long .
Mr Patten , however , is engaged in more than simply relieving his own exasperation at Beijing 's procrastination .
There was a trace of exasperation in his voice as he said : ` I 've told my promoter Dan Duva that I want to fight all those contenders that the people want me to fight .
Plummer wanted to know , a note of exasperation in his voice .
There was a hint of exasperation in his voice .
Shaw , however , worked off most of his exasperation over the weekend winning the Durham and Cleveland County veterans ' over 50 title .
In recent months a growing number of federal judges and lawyers have voiced their exasperation with America 's approach to drugs .
It was a mixture of amusement and exasperation with her friend , with worry added .
And then again perhaps Modigliani 's exasperation stemmed in part from envy of this brilliant young man .
One career wife spoke about her exasperation when her husband listened to her with half an ear as he watched television .
You may find your exasperation turns to inspiration
Now it was the Young King who drew back and , doubtless to their father 's immense exasperation , refused to accept Richard 's homage .
She sounded very disappointed and David knew she was suppressing her exasperation .
Robbie 's exasperation found vent .
Frau Nordern allowed herself a note of exasperation .
“ At least if there 's a human being there you can talk about the deal , ” says Legal & General 's Michael Payne with just a trace of exasperation .
She shot him a look of exasperation .
Your eyesight 's not good enough , " Miss Dersingham said with exasperation .
He was coming so fast that she knew he had not seen her and she had to brake sharply , frowning with exasperation .
` I do n't seem to be getting anywhere with this damn machine , " he said with exasperation .
There was something in the journalist 's manner that goaded Blanche 's exasperation into anger .
There was a hint of exasperation in his voice .
She was single-minded and uncompromising in her work , so that she sometimes provoked exasperation among her colleagues , a feeling immediately tempered by the admiration they felt .
Richard Nixon repeatedly expressed his exasperation at having to work with an unresponsive bureaucracy .
And as the aspirations of the various professions , of students , of the ` third element " rose , so did their exasperation at continuing official inefficiency , corruption and oppression .

All through his life , though Ken could be austere and stubborn to a point which provoked exasperation , his evident holiness was so blended with cheerfulness that he seldom lost the admiration and affection of his contemporaries .
He looked at her with exasperation when she just gazed at him with wide deep blue eyes .
Tzann clucked his tongue with mild exasperation .
He felt a wave of exasperation rise within him .
With a grunt of exasperation , Henry leapt across the room and into the yard , crossing the space between kitchen and dining room until he reached the stables .
He gave a little grunt of exasperation .
How often do parents say in exasperation , ` Oh , you 'll be the death of me " ?
` Damn ! " she muttered in exasperation .
Irina hung up in exasperation .
She was acting like some idiotic schoolgirl , not an intelligent woman , she thought in exasperation .
Jean-Paul gave a sigh of exasperation .
Parkin sighed with exasperation .
With a small sigh of exasperation she thrust her feet to the floor .
